Title.evidence: Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of Peripheral Regional Anaesthesia in Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: Randomisation was performed using computer-generated sequences

Participants.evidence: Participants were eligible if they were 18 years or older.

Intervention.evidence: comparing peripheral nerve blocks to systemic analgesia

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the effectiveness and complications of peripheral nerve blocks compared to systemic analgesia in adult surgical patients.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was block success rate, measured immediately post-surgery.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using computer-generated sequences, with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted on 62 participants in the intervention group and 60 in the control group using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Interscalene blocks for shoulder surgery demonstrated significant pain reduction (mean difference = 2.5, 95% CI 1.5 to 3.5; p < 0.01).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were reported in 3% of the intervention group and 1% of the control group.
